author: LABigAus
body:
Demand was pulled forward due to supply uncertainty, Chinese competitors supported by government (uneconomic) coming online. Slightest price increase in Dram and SK Hynix and Samsung are producing dram in record droves. LRCX said Chinese Dram producers are buying equipment like mad to produce chips for Huawei. This is a very bad sign. 

Mohnish Pabrai and David Tepper love this because they think it’s deep value, but I would stay away. It can always get cheaper. People betting on the US government coming in to protect Micron from serial dumpers in China are foolish. Look at the Trump administration pulling sanctions on and off of Huawei. They won’t do shit to protect this company. China has a made in 2025 plan for a reason, and the government is out to destroy this company to increase dependence on China. Your basically betting on China not fucking you over by going long this. 

Good luck and god speed.

author: CarlFriedrichGauss
body: Why does everyone say they make DRAM? They don't make DRAM, they buy DRAM from Samsung, Micron, or Hynix who effectively control the price and profits of DRAM. Then they slap their logo and some RGB on it and resell it. Anyone can do that. It's a space with a ton of competition. Corsair is no AMD who does their own chip designs, even if TSMC is the one that manufactures the chip. The Corsair IPO is just about tricking clueless investors who have FOMO from AMD and Nvidia.

author: RPMayhem
body:
Moscow Exchange to offer trading in U.S. blue chips from Aug. 24

MOSCOW, Aug 17 (Reuters) - The Moscow Exchange will launch trading of the 19 most liquid shares from the U.S. S&P 500 index on Aug. 24, the bourse said on Monday.

The exchange had earlier planned to offer trading in U.S. blue chips from Aug. 17, in a breakthrough for a long-awaited project which was slowed by Western sanctions.

The exchange will offer shares in Microsoft Corp, Amazon.com Inc, NVIDIA Corp, McDonald's Corp , Facebook Inc, Twitter Inc, Alphabet Inc , Exxon Mobil Corp, Boeing Co, Intel Corp, AT&T Inc, Pfizer Inc, Visa Inc , Netflix Inc, Micron Technology Inc, Activision Blizzard Inc, Walt Disney Co, Advance Micro Devices Inc and Mastercard Inc.

The Moscow Exchange will also start trading Apple Inc shares on Sept. 7.

Russia's largest bourse has said it will add more names from the S&P 500 later this year, planning to trade the stocks in Russian roubles. (Reporting by Andrey Ostroukh and Elena Fabrichnaya; Editing by Mark Potter) Get ready for the putin pumps to combo with our trump pumps. That man knows money is power and has a ton of money so why not buy power via the stock market. Im ok with them buying at this price. Currently buying the ones I think are easily said in Russian. Micron, Exxon, NVDIA, TESLA

author: shitpoststevo
body:
Buying MU calls, 

-NVDA earnings tomorrow, huge, well developed company, works closely with Micron
-Well developed company
-Demand for memory chips and other computer components have risen sharply, shallow inventory, price rise
-Very oversold on the charts
-memory market revenue down 39% this year 
-analysts predict rise of 13%
-micron already has low expectations, if memory market recovers, Micron could have a quick recovery
-Nvidia has high standards, any decrease in revenue could cause a sharp fall
-DRAM prices rose on the second quarter, could be seeing more growth
-Computer component companies have seen monstrous growth during 2020 
          -> AMD up 150% on the year
          ->INTC up 6.25%
          ->NVDA up 180% 

Micron Revenue 
AUG 19: 4.87B
NOV 19:  5.14B
FEB 20: 4.8B
MAY 20: 5.44B

Average EPS before COVID-19: ≈0.5
Feb EPS=0.45
May EPS=0.86 (≈100% increase)

-MU P/E=21
-NVDA P/E=63

author: hammondish
body:
Diversify across big and small... for long term it's all relative, and big = stability with less risk.

I got inti  buying tech stocks around the end of 2016: GOOG, AMZN, FB: about as big as they get, but all were excellent buys and over 100% gains across the board.
On the smaller side, PYPL worked put pretty well too... with slightly more upside: the point is GROWTH POTENTIAL, and CRM has this plus stability.
Makes it, IMO, an ideal investment.

author: CallsCallsCallsCalls
body:
Oh yeah, it's definitely a great one right now, and has been for years actually. I really only meant as a temporary reaction to SQ earnings, and if it was something negative I'd expect it to get bought back up within a few days. 

I think worst case for PYPL is if COVID miraculously disappears. It's still going to have benefitted from all this for a long term.  But a fuckton of money would swing right out of every ATH tech stock to buy the beaten down names. But that scenario is extremely unlikely.

author: ThatOneRedditBro
body:
RAZFF (Razer)

1. Hardware sales are up. Work from home is here to stay. Minimal competitors in the market. They also sell web cams which is a high growth sector.

2. Gaming and eSports is only getting bigger

3. They are experimenting into Fintech which is exploding right now (PayPal, square, crypto) and their financial services sector is growing year of year

4. Their services sector is growing (Razer software)

5. 500 million cash and no debt

6. Competitors like Logitech produced during pandemic and has positive guidance 

One of the top brands for gen z.

All in all they are dabbling in key high growth sectors and delivering on all of them.

author: fateholder
body:
Going with one company makes sense in some scenarios (AMD over INTC for example) when you have expertise/knowledge of the field giving you some edge and a belief that one will outperform the other.

In other scenarios, such as MA v V, I think it makes plenty sense to own both. This field will have more than one winner, and both will coexist well. They also largely move in lockstep with each other, but by diversifying between the two, you do decrease the risk/volatility that each inherently hold (idk like a scandal with one of them, etc.) and its more a bet on the sector/trend sticking with strong companies that will benefit.

For SQ v PYPL, I actually think they are different enough it warrants investing in one or both depending on your view of their individual futures. PYPL is more of a cashless play whereas SQ has both the Seller ecosystem, cashless (cashapp) and Square Store ecosystems.

author: hammondish
body:
I'm with this approach, the roughly $2k I lost trading penny stocks in 2014 was the best money I ever spent: learned the basics of trading, avoiding risk, reading through the hype, and towards the end of that batch of trading found Canopy Growth @$2.00, which turned into my first win (and it offset all my previous losses).  Learned the difference between a hyped up pump-and-dump and a legitimate company, and shifted my focus to more established companies, mainly in tech.

Since then I've followed a strategy similar to what the OP has done, buying stocks whose success is evident in my daily life and companies that demonstrate obvious value to their clients: I work as an IT consultant, so when I see that all my clients are using Paypal, building ecommerce sites with Shopify, and hooking up the CRMs with Salesforce, I research these companies and look for investment opportunities.

1. Stick with what you know

2. Trust your instinct

3. Buy for long term

author: CharlieBrown364
body:
SQ Square

They are a peer-to-peer payment processing company. They have hardware and software that helps small businesses process many types of payments from the customer.

They also have the Cash App, an app similar to PayPal. Users can send and recieve money. Users can also buy cryptocurrencies on the app. The app is growing very rapidly.

author: willyourather
body: I have about 10% or less in ETFs in my portfolio and the rest is in individual stocks. I only do this because I have so many ETFs in my 401k and Roth. Luckily, most of my individual stocks have great returns since I’m a buy and hold investor. For me, AAPL and most tech stocks are winners. I tend to buy companies I know and see in daily life. PayPal, square, Shopify, AMD and amazon are my big holdings. Find stocks that you believe they will grow within 5-10 years and hold on them. Have a tight stop loss when things go down south to the point you are uncomfortable. Good luck!

author: SteamedHamSalad
body: You are right that tech is becoming more and more a part of our lives. But that doesn't mean that straight tech companies are the only way to profit in that situation. Tech permeates all aspects of society. Many of the companies he invests in are on the cutting edge of tech in their industry. In addition, it isn't true that Apple is the only tech company he owns. He also owns stakes in Amazon, VeriSign, and SiriusXM.
